Essentially, yes. 

All the knowledge to hack is held by the â€real Elliotâ€ which allowed hoodie Elliot (the alter we know) to do this thang. And yes, Darlene is a superhero too. 

Everything that happened IS real and did happen, it was just carried out by another facet of â€the realâ€ Elliots (aka the body) psyche which manifeted as hoodie Elliot who is an alter who we all love and know.

Yes. Alters are â€real peopleâ€ so to speak. They are just created in response to immense trauma. 

So if someone has a little, (which is a child alter) that is say maybe, 7 and named Aiden this person, let's say her name is Jessica, even though the body (Jessica) may physically be 27 when aiden fronts Jessica will â€actâ€ like Aiden would, which is a child  

Everything an alter/fragment/part whatever you want to call it when they front- they think, act, talk, move like that person which can be totally different than the body and who that person is at their core- in the case of this show- it's Elliot (the one Darlene sees at the end)

So even though the body may be 27 and named Jessica and maybe is a bartender and has purple hair, when aiden fronts maybe aiden is 7 and loves dinosaurs and coloring and his favorite movie is the little mermaid- Jessica is then essentially â€goneâ€ for the time being. 

Does that clear things up?

Goctha. 

Well just like side note for PC terms and to forward correct info in the world to end the stigma of mental illness but especially this condition; it's not called Multiple Personality Disorder, it's in the DSM-5 now as Dissociative Identity Disorder aka DID  

And I agree I think what you're saying in the last paragraph that it could be interpreted as if the system as a whole has a choice in who fronts. As in the whole thing is to essentially get hoodie Elliot to leave- it doesn't work like that- you can just push people (alters) away unless you are like, super aware of your condition and able to navigate who fronts and even then, that's hard sometimes.
Hmmm. Interesting. Alright right on

Kind of.

So.
I call hoodie Elliot the host because the host is generally the person â€in the drivers seatâ€ so to speak and because he is out (fronting) the whole time.

Thatâ€™s a valid point. But I still feel this was a bit more extreme and explicit than in the past. But you bring up a nice observation.

Yes- I agree I didnâ€™t have to be like â€œ viewer discretion be advised because of INCEST!!!â€ 
They didnâ€™t have to name it directly- it could have been a general warning of sexual assault/abuse. 

And yeah- I was like â€œwtf, why is this a DV hotlineâ€

Oh man, Iâ€™m so sorry for your friend. ðŸ˜¢ I canâ€™t imagine how they are hurting today. Sending them love and healing vibes. 

And I honestly donâ€™t know HOW I feel about- I mean, psychologically speaking, DID is almost always a direct result of childhood abuse so that makes sense that childhood abuse is how he developed DID. But yeah... interesting point.

Woaaaah. Exposure therapy is something that should be done with a *professional clinician* in a controlled, safe environment. 

It is NOT something that people should involuntarily be forced into when they are sitting at home on their couches. 

I understand your view of â€œif you avoid things you retain your traumaâ€ to but thatâ€™s not always the case and TV isnâ€™t the place for healing to necessarily be done. 

Who is to say someone isnâ€™t in a program of going to therapy 3 times a week to work through their trauma and yet, watching this episode or anything else of this nature is still triggered and potentially in crisis again?

Tldr; Tv is not an appropriate way of exposure therapy and it is involuntary to the sufferers of traumatic events.

I knew someone was going to come at me with that weak argument â€œwell then shouldnâ€™t everything have trigger warnings?â€

I understand that people can be triggered by many things due to their unique life experiences and maybe even suffer from PTSD - like you said, car crashes might be activating for some. 

But something as pervasive, triggering and detrimental as sexual abuse and the mere scope-of people it touchesâ€”*That* deserves a warning without question. 

That is CERTAINLY not to say anyone elseâ€™s trauma is invalid or less than. But due to the wide scope of this, it needs to be recognized.
Thank you for validating this. ðŸ–¤

Yes, I definitely get insecure about the number of illnesses I have. How do you tell people you have 8-10 mental illnesses? How do *I* not judge myself because of that and put myself down and feel like shit knowing thatâ€™s my reality?

It bothers me that people self diagnose, because yes- when I say I have 8 (thatâ€™s the number for sure that I always can solidly say but thereâ€™s always a few extra that I forget about) people might think they have the same disorders as I do, when in reality they do not so in the big picture itâ€™s invalidating. It doesnâ€™t make their pain not real or palpable to them, but thereâ€™s a difference between therapists over the course of the past 8 years telling me I have certain conditions.

Congrats on making it that far. Thatâ€™s really admirable. 

I did the same thing 2 years ago- I was well over a year. Probably a year and a half and then I relapsed. 

Since then Iâ€™ve only relapsed 2 times since then and again, that was since 2 years. 

Just remember you made it that far, so you can most certainly do it again, but donâ€™t judge yourself. It happened, itâ€™s over with and now you can continue to heal and get those numbers back up! ðŸ–¤
